@ijuma I had looked for a checkstyle rule to disallow methods, but I couldn't find one. I can add a rule that matches a regex, but that would just be a textual match on the method name followed by (). Do you know of a better way? Thanks.
@auradkar I updated the test, let me know what you think. I think the Jenkins failures are unrelated.
LGTM, cc @gwenshap

In general, lazy initialization does not work perfectly to avoid the problem, but does mitigate the problem a lot: think of a topology where processors are connected sequentially, then upon processing the first store all state stores need to be initialized, which still takes long time. We need to think of an ideal solution for heart beating consumers while doing blocking operations, probably with @hachikuji 's help editing consumer APIs.

Some general feedbacks about this PR:
1. I think it may be OK to do the initialization upon getStore(), instead of each of its operations, since it is usually the case that the processors which needs access to the state store will read / write to it upon getting the first record. But by doing this in getStore we can simply the refactoring a log, like not introducing the `maybeGetPartitions` function.
2. With the above approach, we can get rid of the `initializeStateStores` function, hence we can do the `initializeOffsetLimits` and the full `init(context, store)` call with register in the `getStore` function.
@ewencp PTAL
LGTM

1. Check for array keys in the first "put" call; this is for preventing users define array keys.
2. For internal usage of RocksDBWindowStore, wrap the byte array with ByteBuffer. I did some benchmarking and there is no observable performance difference.
3. Introduce a Bytes util class for comparing and hashing.
4. Fix a few corner case bugs.

@ewencp @ijuma @enothereska @miguno

@guozhangwang  
Changes made to reflect comments:
- removed unnecessary interfaces and processors in favor of using KeyValueMapper and associated processor.
- updated implementation of KTable.toStream(mapper)
Thanks @guozhangwang @ijuma I'll address the above. @guozhangwang agreed on not perfect solution for sequential chain of stores.
Not convinced it was the cause of the test failure , but I updated the names of the topics in the unit tests to be more unique.

It is a bit tricky to simplify this further. Fundamentally there are two steps: 1) upper-part: register stores, their names, etc and 2) bottom-part: initialize the DBs and open files etc. Doing both in `getStore` is tricky, since `getStore` expects step (1) to already be done when it's called.

Also, `StreamTask` internally also expects step (1) to be done since it iterates over all processors in the constructor and does a node.init. This latter often attempts to get a store (e.g., in WordCountProcessorDemo `init` function), i.e., step (1) is needed.
@enothereska You are right. How about rename `initializeStores` to `registerStores` then, and call the init function upon `getStore` on the first time?

@ijuma Thank you, I have changed tests to use Locale.ROOT as well, so that they work regardless of default locale and rerun tests with English and Turkish.

@hachikuji Just made a pass. In general, this is really great. Left some comments for minor cleanup. As we discussed offline, some synchronization stuff in`'WorkerTask` and `WorkerConnector` can be cleaned up a bit.

Addressed github comments, in high-level:

1) Remove the array typed key checking, and warns that usage in the comments.
2) Add Bytes into `o.a.k.common.util`, and BytesSerde to `o.a.k.common.serialization`. 
    Remove all public helper functions from `Bytes` but just use it as an immutable wrapper class.
3) Remove RawChangeLogger.
LGTM, Thanks! Merged to trunk.

@Ishiihara @ewencp Thanks for the reviews. Have a look at the latest commit on handling connector initialization failures. It seemed convenient to handle failures similarly to how we handle them in the tasks: i.e. we treat initialization failures identically to startup or runtime failures and leave the connector in a persistent failed state. Otherwise, you need to invent a new "defunct" state which prohibits startup (since we wouldn't want to even try starting a connector if it failed to initialize). This means that the user must use /restart to restart a failed connector, which is a little different from the initial patch which allowed the usage of /resume to restart a failed connector.

@hachikuji The exception handling looks good. This seems to fix the bug reported by C3 team. In case of errors during connector initialization or start, reconfiguration will not be invoked. The consequences of this is that the tasks for this connector will not be initialized and started. One question though, restart may not work in case of incorrect configs as it will fail again. We probably need to destroy the connector in this case and submit a new one with the correct configs.
@hachikuji Another question is that why do we use `TARGET_STATE_KEY(connector)` in `removeConnectorConfig` of in `KafkaConfigBackingStore.java`, shouldn't we use `CONNECTOR_KEY` instead?
@junrao Will you be able to review the latest changes so that this can be committed for 0.10.0? I have rebased and started another system test run. Thank you.
LGTM
@guozhangwang Just updated this. Please give feedback.
@junrao sorry for the delay with this. Fell of my radar. I've made the rename you suggested. Could you please merge. Thanks

@Ishiihara Thanks for taking another look. For `removeConnectorConfig`, there are two parts: removal of the connector's configuration and removal of the target state. The first is handled in `updateConnectorConfig`.
@guozhangwang @gwenshap re: discussion of "integration" tests that are really system tests, this one looks to be a strict subset of the ReplicationTest so I think we can just get rid of it entirely.

On connector failures, there are definitely cases where restarting won't help. In those cases, we hope the exception provides enough information for the user to fix the problem before trying to restart. However, I don't think the framework should necessarily try to detect this situation and attempt any cleanup itself. Does that make sense?

LGTM.

Nothing makes me happier than merging code-deletions in the morning :)
@hachikuji Thanks for the explanation. I missed the `updateConnnectorConfig` part.

@ewencp ping for initial review

There are some rough edges and unfinished bits, but It would be great to get feedback on the overall approach and path resolution api.

As we discussed offline recently, it's possible we want to change "path resolution" to something more general. From my vantage point, this is fairly extensible, but ideas here are welcome as well.

Note that running tests here relies on logic in the `user-defined-globals` branch of ducktape.

LGTM. We have a few follow up items, we should file follow up JIRAs for anything that's not going to followed up on immediately. Thanks for all the work on this patch, @hachikuji, turned out to be slightly more involved than anticipated.

BTW, this bug can be fixed in RecordBatch.tryAppend() by returning null  for RecordBatches with no. of. send attempts > 0

@omkreddy, thanks for adding the unit test. Can you also add a test that checks that producer retries actually work? That way, we can change implementation in the future and still have that checked.

@ijuma  Actually there is no issue with Producer retries.  The issue is simultaneous process of new records and old recordbatch retries may cause IllegalStateException for some new records. 

Still, I will try to write appropriate testcase for this scenario.
